questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer has deployed the Cisco CMX solution to track and detect the number of users who visit the office each day. The CMX dashboard is not showing any data. Which action resolves this issue?

choices.D: Install an evaluation license to CMX server.
choices.C: Copy the exported Maps from CMX server to PI using SCP.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
For the Cisco CMX (Connected Mobile Experiences) solution to track and detect users, it needs to receive data from the Wireless LAN Controllers (WLCs). If the WLCs are not added to the CMX server, the CMX dashboard will not show any data because it has no source of information about client devices and their movements.

A. Configure Single Sign-On authentication: While Single Sign-On (SSO) might be useful for user access management, it is unrelated to the CMX dashboard's ability to collect and display data.

C. Copy the exported Maps from CMX server to PI using SCP: This step is related to map management and is not necessary for enabling data collection from WLCs.

D. Install an evaluation license to CMX server: Licensing issues might prevent certain features from working, but the absence of data on the dashboard is more likely due to the WLCs not being added to the CMX server.

Selected Answer: D
On the top of the screenshot you will see 5 APs - so APs already have been added. Moreover we see already a map
If you regard this and it must be D

comments.content: CMX provide 120-day evaluation license when first active, if license expires, you will not be able to access the Cisco CMX GUI or APIs. So i think B is correct.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
correct
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/mse/10-4/cmx_config/b_cg_cmx104/the_cisco_cmx_detect_and_locate_service.html#:~:text=Wireless%20Controllers.-,Add%20controllers,-%E2%80%94For%20information%20about

choices.C: aaa accounting exec acct_method start-stop group rad-group
choices.A: aaa accounting identity acct_method start-stop group rad-group
choices.B: aaa accounting network acct_method start-stop group rad-group
choices.D: aaa accounting commands acct_method start-stop group rad-group

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
To enable RADIUS profiling on the Cisco Catalyst 9800 Series Controller, the controller must send client-related information (such as MAC address, device type, and other attributes) to the Cisco ISE server. This is achieved by configuring identity accounting in the AAA method list. The command aaa accounting identity ensures that the controller forwards client identity information to the RADIUS server (ISE) for profiling purposes.

Why This Configuration?
Identity Accounting: RADIUS profiling relies on identity accounting to send client-specific information to the ISE server. This includes details like MAC address, device type, and other attributes required for profiling.

RADIUS Server Group: The group rad-group specifies the RADIUS server group (ISE server) to which the accounting data is sent.

comments.content:
B. aaa accounting network acct_method start-stop group rad-group: This command is used for network session accounting, which is not directly related to profiling client devices.

C. aaa accounting exec acct_method start-stop group rad-group: This command is used for exec (login) session accounting, which is unrelated to client profiling.

D. aaa accounting commands acct_method start-stop group rad-group: This command is used for command-level accounting, which tracks specific commands executed on the device. It is not used for profiling client devices.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Agreed

Selected Answer: A
A. - https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/san/command/ibns-xe-3se-5700-cr-book/san-xe-3se-5700-cr-book_chapter_00.html#wp3946943986

Selected Answer: A
Agreed

Selected Answer: A
Should "identity".
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless/catalyst-9800-series-wireless-controllers/215661-in-depth-look-into-client-profiling-on-9.html#anc12

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A network architect configured the Cisco Catalyst 9800 Series Controller to find out information on client types in the wireless network. RADIUS profiling is enabled so that the controller forwards the information about clients to a Cisco ISE server through vendor-specific RADIUS attributes. The ISE server is not profiling any data from the controller. Which configuration must be added in the blank in the code to accomplish the profiling on the Cisco 9800 Series controller?

Company XYZ recently migrated from AireOS to IOS XE 9800 WLCs. The Internet bandwidth must be limited to 5 Mbps for each guest client as per the global standard. In which configuration on the Cisco Catalyst 9800 WLC must the QoS requirement be added?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
To limit the Internet bandwidth to 5 Mbps for each guest client on the Cisco Catalyst 9800 WLC, you need to configure a policy map. A policy map is used to define the QoS (Quality of Service) policies, including bandwidth limits, for specific traffic classes.

Steps to Configure:
Create a Class Map: Define a class map to classify the guest client traffic.

Create a Policy Map: Apply the bandwidth limit (5 Mbps) to the guest client traffic using the policy map.

Apply the Policy Map: Attach the policy map to the appropriate interface or WLAN.

comments.content:
To limit the Internet bandwidth to 5 Mbps for each guest client on the Cisco Catalyst 9800 WLC, you need to configure a policy map. A policy map is used to define the QoS (Quality of Service) policies, including bandwidth limits, for specific traffic classes.

Steps to Configure:
Create a Class Map: Define a class map to classify the guest client traffic.

Create a Policy Map: Apply the bandwidth limit (5 Mbps) to the guest client traffic using the policy map.

Apply the Policy Map: Attach the policy map to the appropriate interface or WLAN.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
If you check the IOS-XE CLI configuration you will see that the bandwidth limit police is set into the class map

comments.content:
Steps to Implement:
Create a class map to classify guest client traffic.

Create a policy map to define the 5 Mbps bandwidth limit for the classified traffic.

Apply the policy map to the appropriate WLAN or interface using a service policy.

Thus, the QoS requirement must be added to the policy map.
You ingress to policy-map mode then select the class-map and ingress to sub mode and only then you set the police but you are inside policy-map, in class-map you match traffic.
You ingress to policy-map mod then match the class-map and ingress to sub mode and only then you set the policy but you are inside policy-map, in class-map you match traffic.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I agree with Policy-map. Service-policy only apply Policy-map to an interface. And class-map is only part of policy-map.

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D

None of these.

A 'QoS Client Policy' is the true answer which gets applied within a Policy Profile.
The policy is created under the global QoS section. It matches traffic based on a Class-Map (potentially) and then polices that traffic.

choices.D: msl qos trust cos configured on the controller switch port
choices.C: msl qos trust dscp configured on the controller switch port
choices.A: Platinum QoS configured on the WLAN
choices.B: WMM set to required on the WLAN

questions.question_text: An engineer wants the wireless voice traffic class of service to be used to determine the queue order for packets received, and then have the differentiated services code point set to match when it is resent to another port on the switch. Which configuration is required in the network?

comments.content: I think andit's explanation is right

You gave the right surce, but the wrong answer: 
"When you enter the mls qos trust dscp command on a port, (...) When the packet is resent on another port, the switch sets the CoS tag to match the DSCP so there is no conflict between the two values"
This is exactly what the questions asks. 
The "mls qos trust cos" command, like you wrote just makes the DSCP value correspond to the CoS. But the case of the packet resenting to another port is not handled here.

discussion.content:
The Correct Answer is D.
"When you enter the mls qos trust cos command on a port, the switch uses the CoS marking on incoming packets in order to put the packet in the right queue. When the packet is resent, the switch makes the DSCP value correspond to the CoS."
See: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless-mobility/voice-over-wireless-lan-vowlan/116056-technote-qos-00.html#anc3

Answer is C.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless-mobility/voice-over-wireless-lan-vowlan/116056-technote-qos-00.html#:~:text=When%20you%20enter,to%20the%20CoS.

"Set to match" vs "correspond to"

Selected Answer: D
In a wireless QoS deployment, voice traffic needs to be prioritized throughout the network. The Class of Service (CoS) values are assigned based on 802.1p (Layer 2 QoS), while Differentiated Services Code Point (DSCP) values are used for Layer 3 QoS.

✔ mls qos trust cos ensures that the switch trusts the CoS value assigned by the WLC and maps it to the appropriate DSCP value for end-to-end QoS.

Selected Answer: D
Concentrate on the wording. DSCP to correspond to CoS. Answer is D.

The engineer wants to use the wireless voice traffic class of service to determine the queue order for packets received. This means that Quality of Service (QoS) needs to be configured to prioritize voice traffic.
“cos” stands for Class of Service, which is typically used for Ethernet frames and not specifically designed for voice traffic prioritization.
In this case, the engineer wants to prioritize voice traffic using the wireless voice traffic class of service, which is better achieved by trusting the Differentiated Services Code Point (DSCP) value rather than the Class of Service (COS) value.
Therefore, option D is not the right configuration, and option C, “msl qos trust dscp configured on the controller switch port,” is the correct configuration required in the network.
D is correct - trust cos

Selected Answer: D
Ignore the reference to DSCP upon resend. It is meant to throw you off and is irrelevant to what the question is asking.

The key ask here is to use the CoS to determine queue order for frames received on a switch.

Selected Answer: D
Answer D. I agree with andit explanation.

Selected Answer: C
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless-mobility/voice-over-wireless-lan-vowlan/116056-technote-qos-00.html#:~:text=When%20you%20enter,to%20the%20CoS.
not msl qos.. but mls qos

Selected Answer: A
If WLAN QoS is default, the voice class of service will be rewritten to default on the controller.
Platinum QoS must be enabled to maintain class of service for received voice packets.
Correct answer is D because the engineer was the voice traffic CLASS OF SERVICE to be used. So we're wanting to trust COS and have the switch then remark DSCP to match.
C dscp
Provided answer is correct
Correct answer is D
answer is D
I think is A, because that commands are globally enable, not per port. And the answer talk about mark the traffic on the wireless, so the need to implement QoS on the wireless.

Selected Answer: C
To grant an engineer read/write access to rename access points and add them to the correct AP groups on a wireless controller using Cisco ISE TACACS, the minimum required custom attributes are:

role1=WLAN

role2=WIRELESS

These roles provide the necessary permissions for managing wireless LAN configurations, including renaming access points and assigning them to AP groups.

Why These Roles?
role1=WLAN: Grants access to WLAN-related configurations.

role2=WIRELESS: Grants access to wireless-specific configurations, including AP management.

Why Not the Other Options?
A. role1=WLAN: This role alone does not provide sufficient permissions for AP management tasks like renaming and adding to AP groups.

B. role1=WLAN role2=SECURITY: The SECURITY role is related to security configurations and is not required for AP management tasks.

D. role1=WIRELESS: This role alone does not provide sufficient permissions for WLAN-related configurations.

Selected Answer: C
correct

Selected Answer: C
WLAN + WIRELESS tabs

Selected Answer: C
Renaming APs is in the Wireless Tab, setting APs into AP-Groups is in the WLAN tab, so choice C includes both.

Selected Answer: A
Almost got tripped up on this one. "A" would be correct for this question's requirement. When passing attributes from ISE to the controller, the role command implies the tab the user can access/manage. In this case, the Engineer requires minimum access to manage the AP Groups, which would be on the "WLAN" (AP Groups) tab of the AireOS controller.

ISE Config: https://youtu.be/GN8xUhg_5TI?t=59

"To move APs, click the AP group name, choose the APs tab, check the check box to the left of the AP name, or select the AP name check box to select all APs, and click the Add APs." - https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/8-1/olh/wlc-olh-81/wlansc.html#84757

Still new to all of this of course, so this is just from what I could find.

comments.content: You forgot that the other requirement was to rename Access Points, which can be found in the Wireless tab, so WLAN and Wireless are both required

questions.question_text: An engineer needs read/write access to rename access points and add them to the correct AP groups on a wireless controller. Using Cisco ISE TACACS, which custom attributes is the minimum required?
